author: David Swan
title: Facebook testing ‘dislike’ button
text:
It’s been something some users have been demanding for years - a ‘dislike’ button to balance Facebook’s ‘like’ button - and CEO Mark Zuckerberg has confirmed the controversial feature is in testing.
Mr Zuckerberg used a public Q&A session to reveal he has a team of engineers working on the dislike button, which he said would be a tool to “express empathy” rather than cause hurt to someone.
"People have asked about the 'Dislike' button for many years ... and today is a special day, because today is the day that I actually get to say we are working on it and are very close to shipping a test of it,” Mr Zuckerberg told the forum.
"We don't want to turn Facebook into a forum where people are voting up or down on people's posts,” he said.
"That doesn't seem like the kind of community that we want to create: you don't want to go through the process of sharing some moment that was important to you in your day and have someone downvote it.
"If you are sharing something that is sad...then it may not feel comfortable to 'like' that post,” Mr Zuckerberg said.
Fellow social media platform Reddit, which allows for upvoting and dowvoting, has come under heavy fire over recent months for allowing bullying and a culture that has been described as misogynistic.
New Reddit CEO Steve Huffman has promised to clamp down on the site's culture of bullying and has introduced new rules in a bid to clean up Reddit's public image.
No more information was provided on Facebook’s dislike feature and it’s unclear whether it will ever see a public release.
Mr Zuckerberg also discussed artificial intelligence, a hot topic given increasing concerns around lost jobs and the future of warfare, describing himself as an optimist.
"I think that it's a little dangerous to be too negative about the prospect of something long term when all signs point to that over the next 10, 20, 30 years—whatever it is—we're going to unlock all this value and help people's lives so much by developing this technology," he said.
"So I'm an optimist."
